generated_text: This work is a major advance in the study of the structure of ice, which is the most important phase of water in nature.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a categorical characterization of the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces, which is the mathematical setting for quantum mechanics. Our characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This provides a new perspective on the nature of quantum theory and may be of interest to researchers in the field.
This study is a major advance in our understanding of the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle. It is also a significant contribution to the study of the evolution of the animal kingdom as a whole.
This is a study of the role of a protein in the spread of a disease.
This is a study of the role of a metal ion in the function of a protein.

We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, and that this increase will be larger in the tropics than in the temperate zones. This will have important implications for the stability of global grain trade and for the livelihoods of the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which different species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level plant remains in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in body size and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work highlights the importance of diet composition in the study of niche partitioning and biodiversity. (Less)

This paper is about the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on small businesses. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020. Several themes emerged. First, mass layoffs and closures had already occurred—just a few weeks into the crisis. Second, the risk of closure was negatively associated with the expected length of the crisis. Moreover, businesses had widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of COVID-related disruptions. Third, many small businesses are financially fragile: The median business with more than $10,000 in monthly expenses had only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Fourth, the majority of businesses planned to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipated problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility. Using experimental variation, we also assess take-up rates and business resilience effects for loans relative to grants-based programs.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of the plastic debris on the open ocean surface, which are not accounted for in the current models. These sinks are likely to be of a global nature, and they may be of a similar magnitude for other types of debris.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and enigmatic questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the sun and the planets. The age of the solar system is one of the most important parameters in the study of the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. View Full-Text
The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the offspring is a major determinant of reproductive output.
This study is a proof of concept of the potential of a drug that was well tolerated in a clinical trial in patients with epilepsy to slow down the progression of a neurodegenerative disorder.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for a wide range of functions, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between the blood and the tissues. This paper describes the nature of the communication system between the endothelial cells and the nature of the network that is used to control the functions of the endothelium. The findings are important for understanding the nature of the communication system that is used to control the functions of the endothelium and for understanding the nature of the network that is used to control the functions of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data has never been greater. We present the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides a comprehensive set of signals of COVID-19 activity at a fine geographic resolution. The data are available in a common format, and are updated daily. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, for epidemiological model development, and for research and decision-making. The data are also available for use in research and development of new applications.
This work is about the structure and function of potassium channels.

This study is a first step in the characterization of the natural products of anaerobic fungi, which are important members of the gut microbiome. The results of this study provide a foundation for future studies of the biosynthesis of natural products by anaerobic fungi, as well as the potential for these fungi to be used as a source of natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, and the study of the factors that determine who becomes dominant is of great interest. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of developing a subordinate status in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. View Full-Text

This work is about the design of mechanical structures that can be deformed to arbitrary shapes and motions. The design is based on the synthesis of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct mechanical properties. The synthesized structures are then fabricated into devices with programmable and complex responses. The proposed design and fabrication strategy can be applied to a wide range of applications, such as soft robotics, energy harvesting, and structural engineering.
This is a study of the role of a gene in the development of the human body.
This study is a major advance in the field of cancer therapy, as it provides a mechanism for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.
This is a study of the effects of a class of drugs on the heart.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational methods in the rational design of antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other classes of antibiotics and to other targets of interest. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that this work will be useful for the community in the development of deep learning methods for image processing.

This study is the first to provide a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability from a single lake. The results show that the evolution of the Lake Malawi basin was shaped by large-scale changes in effective moisture, which resulted in dramatic shifts in the size of the lake and the evolution of the lake ecosystem. The study also shows that the evolution of the Lake Malawi basin was shaped by large-scale changes in effective moisture, which resulted in dramatic shifts in the size of the lake and the evolution of the lake ecosystem.

This study is the first to show that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have a significant impact on the following night’s sleep. The results of this study have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The cause of the 12.9-ka global cooling is a matter of debate. One hypothesis is that a bolide impact triggered the cooling. However, the evidence for such an impact is not conclusive. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in the United States is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding spherules that are likely ejecta from an impact 12.9 ka ago.
This is a study of the role of a molecule that is essential for the development of tolerance, but that is also essential for the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, and the origin of this diversity is a key question in the history of life. We provide the most comprehensive dataset to date on the evolution of beetles, and use it to resolve the evolutionary history of this group, including the role of horizontal gene transfers in the evolution of their digestive systems.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
This paper is about the evolution of technology, and the role of social learning in that evolution.
This is a study of the role of a protein in the development of a disease.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the core and the evolution of the planet. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. This work provides a solution to the long-standing paradox of the inner core formation, which has been a major obstacle in understanding the core formation.
This study is about the effects of marijuana on the brain. It is about the brain’s response to the drug, and the brain’s response to the drug is about the brain’s response to the drug.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are only now beginning to be understood. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to show that the most powerful models of language processing in the brain are also the best predictors of how listeners understand sentences, across many datasets and many models. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the brain’s comprehension of language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, the stability of DL has been a major concern. We show that the stability of DL is closely related to the existence of algorithms that can compute it. We prove that there are cases where no algorithm can compute a stable DL model, and we also prove that there are cases where a stable DL model can be computed using only a few training samples. Our results provide a classification theory of the stability of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It is also a major source of public debate. In this context, the role of psychology in the pandemic is a matter of great concern. In this paper, we discuss the role of a classic psychological experiment in the spread of the disease.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still with us today. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disease in the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the disease in the skin. This study shows that the two bacteria are very similar, and that they have been very similar for a long time.

Entanglement and entropy are the two key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. The study of the time evolution of these quantities is therefore of central importance. However, the entanglement dynamics is notoriously difficult to compute, and so far only for noninteracting systems. We show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, and we check it for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

This study describes the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only vaccine currently in clinical development. The vaccine is expected to be a cost-effective and scalable vaccine for mass vaccination programs.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was one of the deadliest epidemics in human history. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. However, there is no direct evidence for this. Here, we present a model for the spread of plague by human fleas, which is the most likely vector for the disease in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by fleas, challenging the assumption that plague was predominantly spread by rats. This has important implications for the history of the disease and for the development of plague control measures.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important and fascinating topics in biology. However, the evolution of brain size is biased by the selection pressures of the body size, which is the main determinant of the size of the skull. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is better understood by using the number of neurons rather than the size of the brain. The results show that the evolution of the brain is not only different from that of the body size but also different in birds and mammals. This has important implications for the study of the evolution of brain size and the evolution of cognition.
This is a study of the role of a protein in the development of cancer.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell migration, cell division, and the regulation of the cell cycle. However, the mechanism by which it acts is not fully understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF is strongly influenced by the mechanical state of the filament network. We propose that this mechanism is critical to the function of ADF in cells.

This study is the first to show that the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain and behavior are dependent on the fasted state. These findings have implications for the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce the risk of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the conservation of the island’s biodiversity. View Full-Text

We show that the content of a person’s Facebook News Feed can influence that person’s emotions. We also show that the content of a person’s Facebook News Feed can influence that person’s emotions. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results have implications for the design of social networks, as well as for the study of the spread of emotions in social networks. They also suggest that the observation of others’ negative experiences can be a negative experience for people.

This work is about the ribosome, the protein that reads the genetic code, and the messenger RNA (mRNA) that tells the ribosome what protein to make. The work is also about the role of mRNA modifications in the process of protein synthesis.

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and they are also evident in a longitudinal analysis, indicating that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting positive outcomes over the life course.
This paper is about the evolution of body size in mammals, and in particular, the evolution of mammals into the water.

This study is a continuation of our previous work on the role of temperature in the replication of rhinovirus, the common cold virus. We show that the replication of rhinovirus is more efficient at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the replication of rhinovirus is dependent on the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record
This is a study of the role of the mechanical properties of a bacterial surface in the regulation of gene expression.

This study is the first of its kind to provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation. It shows that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. The results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.
This study is a first step in understanding the role of deer in the COVID-19 pandemic. The findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is being ignored by the hydropower industry. This paper examines the problems of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

This work is a major advance in the study of the role of the immune system in Alzheimer’s disease, and in particular, in the earliest stages of the disease. The results are also of interest to the general field of neuroinflammation, since they demonstrate that the brain is a dynamic environment, in which the immune system is constantly responding to the changing environment.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. The domestication of the chicken is a complex process that took place over a period of several millennia. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken is from the Near East, and the earliest evidence for the economic use of the chicken is from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. This study shows that the earliest evidence for the economic use of the chicken in Europe is predated by at least a century by the earliest evidence in the Near East.

This is a study of the folding of a large protein. It is a study of the folding of a large protein in which the structure of the intermediate is determined by the sequence of the protein. It is a study of the folding of a large protein in which the structure of the intermediate is determined by the sequence of the protein.
This is a study of the role of a protein in the degradation of a type of RNA.

This study is a contribution to the understanding of the mechanisms involved in the development of the immunosuppression observed in sepsis, and to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of this condition.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature, where systems with no external control mechanism exhibit criticality, a state of maximum efficiency. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including quantum devices, solar cells, and lasers. However, the bandgap of diamond is not fully metallic, and it is not fully semiconducting. This work shows that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work also shows that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

This work is about the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are derived from the immune system of the model legume Medicago truncatula. These peptides are expressed in the root nodule of the plant, where they are thought to play a role in the defense against fungal pathogens. The work is also about the structural and functional characterization of these peptides, which is important for the development of these peptides as a new class of fungicides.
This work is about the role of the female reproductive tract in the life cycle of the sperm.
This work is about the role of force in the regulation of a protein that is essential for the control of blood clotting.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that are essential for human health. However, the role of viruses in the human microbiome is just as important, and may be even more significant. This study is the first to provide a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, and is a critical resource for future research.

Aerosols are one of the most important factors in the climate system. However, the impact of aerosols on clouds is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) process. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of the surface of the Earth is a key factor in the evolution of life. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past, based on the thermostability of enzymes.
This is a study of the structure and function of a potassium channel.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the host cell that it uses to spread throughout the body. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the malaria parasite is, in fact, a balance of forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has important implications for the development of antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including quantum devices, photonics, and energy storage. However, the bandgap of diamond is not fully metallic, and it is not fully semiconducting. This work shows that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work also shows that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

This study is about the impact of dry air on the host response to influenza infection. The results are important for understanding the impact of dry air on the spread of influenza virus, and for the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza on human health.
This paper is about the brain’s processing of language, and in particular about the nature of the brain’s representation of the structure of sentences.
This is a study of the regulation of gene expression in the context of a pathway.
This work is about the brain circuits that control the urge to eat.
This work is about the control of the symbiosis between plants and bacteria, which is essential for the growth of both plants and bacteria.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the web of a spider is a hyperacute acoustic antenna that can detect the motion of air particles, which is the fundamental property of hearing. The spider can localize the source of the sound and even sense the direction of the sound. This is a unique feature of the spider, which can sense the direction of the sound and can adjust the size of the acoustic sensor according to the need.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

This work is a contribution to the global fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. The work is a continuation of our previous work on the design of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein, which has been used in the development of vaccines and other products. The work is also a continuation of our work on the design of a virus-like particle (VLP) that can be used to deliver the RBD protein.
This is a study of the role of a protein in the development of a particular type of skin cell.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis is responsible for the deaths of millions of people throughout the world. The timing of the emergence of plague is still debated, and the study of ancient DNA has provided a unique window into the past. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period in the development of the pathogen. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide a unique perspective on the early evolution and ecology of plague. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the support of Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM was associated with support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for the study of gender, race, and class in the United States and beyond.

This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols can have a significant impact on soil organic carbon storage. The results of this study are important for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices that can mitigate the effects of agricultural land use change on the global carbon cycle.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a critical step in the development of a

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is important for attracting pollinators, but the mechanisms by which plants produce and use pigments to do so are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes necessary for the production of this pigment, which are likely to be involved in other types of color production in plants. Our work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of this type of adaptation and the role of alkaloids in it.

We present the genomes of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we find that women with artificial skull deformations had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of the rest of the population. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.
This is a study of the transmission of a virus from animals to humans.

This study is a proof of concept for the use of next-generation sequencing in the study of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. The study is also a demonstration of the use of the cloud-based platform, IDseq, for the analysis of metagenomic data. The study is a demonstration of the use of the cloud-based platform, IDseq, for the analysis of metagenomic data.
This is a study of the structure and function of a protein complex that is essential for the survival of the human species.

The origin of life is one of the most important, yet enigmatic, problems in science. In this work, we describe the development of a system that can replicate and amplify nucleic acids in the absence of proteins. This system is the first of its kind, and it is a significant step toward the reconstruction of the origins of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is also a demonstration of the value of using computer vision methods to measure the physical appearance of cities.

This study is the first report of the clinical efficacy of tocilizumab in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results show that tocilizumab can reduce the mortality of COVID-19 patients, and the treatment is safe and effective.
This is a study of the role of a natural product in the maintenance of homeostasis of a micronutrient.
This paper is about the origin of the rocks on Mars, and in particular, the origin of the rocks in the crater of Gale crater, Mars.

Frost events are a major cause of crop and animal losses, and the economic impact of these events is expected to increase in the future. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the evolutionary history of the species that are most affected by them.
This is a study of the role of Th17 cells in the development of inflammatory bowel disease.
This is a study of the role of astrocytes in ALS.
This is a study of the role of the microbiota in the transmission of a pathogen by an arthropod vector.
This paper is about the evolution of the modern bird body plan, and in particular the evolution of the tail.
We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the Earth.
This study is about the evolution of a color, and the function of a protein.
This is a study of the role of a gene in the development of cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports the results of a study of 465 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, to determine the origin of the animal skins used to make them. The results suggest that the use of fetal animals was not necessary to produce the first pocket Bibles.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key control on the timing of ecosystem recovery and on the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.
This is a study of the role of a transcription factor in the development of a disease.

This study is a major contribution to the understanding of the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. The structure of the spike protein is important for understanding the mechanism of infection, and for the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
Simplified version: We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the study of the properties of molecules and materials. We show that the chemical properties of atoms, as a function of pressure, are consistent with the emergence of new chemical phenomena, such as the formation of new compounds and the appearance of new crystal structures. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the emergence of new chemical phenomena. This work is a major advance in the study of the chemical properties of atoms and their evolution under pressure.

We show that the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on the global fire regime are likely to be more important in determining future climate change than changes in climate itself. This is because of feedbacks between fire and the carbon cycle, which can reduce warming by up to 10 y of CO2 emissions. Our results suggest that the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on the global fire regime are likely to be more important in determining future climate change than changes in climate itself.
This is a study of the role of a single molecule in the evolution of a symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in machine learning and draws on the strengths of topic modeling and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward the goal of understanding the world in text.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in Europe. However, the history of the plague in Europe is more complex than this narrative suggests. We show that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y between each introduction. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of introductions, rather than a single introduction, and that the disease was not established in Europe until the end of the 14th century.
This is a study of the role of a virus in the mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The disease is associated with the expression of the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) on leukemic stem cells, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach has the potential to be used in combination with other therapies, and it may be applicable to other types of cancer. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization of the island. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it has implications for the settlement of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text
This is a study of the role of a small RNA in the regulation of metabolism.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, the information they provide is subjective and difficult to aggregate. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey of the US Department of Agriculture can be used to derive a continuous, probabilistic measure of crop status, which is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index is a powerful tool for monitoring crop status and predicting crop yields, and can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this function in the brain. Information is stored in the dynamics of the membrane potential, but this information is also read back into the system through dynamic variables that control the rate of adaptation. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to the context of the word in a sentence, and it is sensitive to the order of the words in a sentence. This mechanism is not dependent on synaptic plasticity or persistent activity, and it is not dependent on feedback.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and find that the response of soil respiration to warming is highly variable across biomes. Our results provide evidence that soil respiration may not be increasing as rapidly as previously thought in many regions, and that the response of soil respiration to warming may be highly dependent on the biome.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in the study of the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the evolutionary rate of the plastid genome is a function of the degree of functional reduction, which in turn is a function of the lifestyle of the host.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a call to action for the international community to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe impacts of climate change. View Full-Text
The discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is of great interest to the fields of materials science, history, and science communication.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key feature of (bacterio)chlorophylls, is a major unsolved problem in biology. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia was associated with a reduction in disease severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record
We find that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to anthropogenic warming.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the etiology is not fully understood. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. (PsycINFO Database Record)

This work is a cross-national replication of a 2015 study that found that people react more strongly to negative than positive information. The current work extends this research in several important ways. First, it is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. Second, it is the first to report results from a 17-country, 6-continent study. Third, it is the first to report results from a study that is not based on a small sample of Anglo-American participants. Fourth, it is the first to report results from a study that is not based on a single news source. Fifth, it is the first to report results from a study that is not based on a single news genre. Finally, it is the first to report results from a study that is not based on a single news outlet.
This is a study of the role of a channel in the transmission of information in the body.
This work is about the spread of disease in the brain.

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to suppress the host immune system and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this protein. (Show more)
This is a study of the role of a metabolic enzyme in cancer.
This is a study of the role of protein aggregation in the development of a disease.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device is fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These devices can be deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is a significant step toward the realization of a new platform for quantum matter studies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the origin of the flowering plants is complicated by the fact that the fossils of this group are very rare. This study presents a detailed analysis of Montsechia, a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. The study of Montsechia has led to a better understanding of the morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction. The study also raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the fields of virology and phylogenetics. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which are of great interest to the fields of virology and phylogenetics. We find that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)
We provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise due to climate change, which is expected to continue for the next century.

Pain is a normal part of life, but the experience of pain changes with age. We show that, on average, pain increases with age in the United States, but that the rate of increase is higher for those born after 1950.

This work is a demonstration of the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a reaction intermediate in an enzyme active site. The work is also a demonstration of the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a reaction intermediate in an enzyme active site.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus, and is a major public health concern. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum antiviral that has been shown to inhibit the replication of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)-CoV virus. Here, we show that remdesivir is also effective against the MERS-CoV virus, and that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir can prevent and treat MERS-CoV infection, respectively, in a nonhuman primate model. These data support the use of remdesivir in the context of a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to the global community.
This is a study of the role of a single molecule in the evolution of a symbiosis.

This research is about the importance of the quality of teacher–student relationships in the classroom, and the role that teachers’ mindsets play in shaping those relationships. It is also about the importance of the quality of teacher–student relationships in the classroom, and the role that teachers’ mindsets play in shaping those relationships.
This work is about the impact of alkylation on the function of DNA polymerases. It is a very important topic in the field of DNA repair and mutagenesis.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. The virus infects humans from animals, and the virus is transmitted between humans. The virus is sensitive to many of the same antiviral agents used to treat other coronaviruses, and it is a major cause of pneumonia in dromedary camels. The virus infects human cells by fusing the virus-containing membrane with the cell membrane, a process that requires the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We show that the S proteins are cleaved sequentially during virus entry, and that the first cleavages are required for the virus to infect human cells. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, and for the development of antiviral agents. (Less)

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is likely that the proportion of vegetarian meals could be increased further. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. The results also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people to make more sustainable food choices in other domains, such as the choice of car to buy. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors. The results are based on a large number of diners, and the effect is likely to be even larger in smaller settings. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors. The results are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounding factors

This is a study of the surfaceome, the proteins that are attached to the surface of the cell. This is a very large protein collection, and the study is a major advance in the field of proteomics. The study is also a major advance in the study of cancer, as it provides a view of how specific oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion.

Vote-by-mail is a popular policy that has been adopted in many countries around the world. In the United States, however, vote-by-mail is not the norm. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.
This is a study of the structure and function of a protein that is a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with neuronal apoptosis and increased expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4), corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to up-regulation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. Finally, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. These results provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The problem is that we have “cherry-picked”—searched for the strongest associations—and so must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a challenge that is becoming more important as the size of the dataset increases and the tools for cherry picking become more sophisticated.
This study is about the development of the blood vessels in the body.
This is a study of the role of a protein in the development of the eye and the skin.

This study is a major advance in the field of diabetes research, as it provides a mechanism for the role of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and insulin secretion. This study also provides a potential target for the treatment of type 2 diabetes.

This work is about the packaging of the influenza virus genome. The genome of the influenza virus is made up of eight segments of RNA. The packaging of the viral genome is essential for the production of the viral particles. The packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, and the details of the process are not fully understood. This work describes a mechanism that is involved in the packaging of the viral genome.

This study is a continuation of our previous work on the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis. We have found that YAP/TAZ are activated by disturbed flow in the endothelium and that this activation is required for the development of atheroprone phenotypes. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the coterminous United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is also a demonstration of the value of using computer vision methods to measure the physical appearance of cities.

This study is about the role of natural repellents in the evolution of arthropods, and the importance of the scorpion as a model organism in the study of the molecular mechanisms of the perception of these compounds.

This work is a contribution to the global effort to understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and control of the Zika virus, which has been associated with a number of serious health problems. The work is also a contribution to the field of mathematical modeling of infectious diseases, which has been used to understand the spread of the virus, the effect of control measures, and the development of antiviral drugs.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the early stages of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.
This work is about the importance of the microbiome in the development of cancer.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is a major determinant of the outcome of the disease. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this up-regulation is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. We also show that the expression of ROR1 is associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with either chemotherapy alone. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation is often defined as the time when the last ice sheets started to retreat. However, the timing of the start of deglaciation is not only important for the timing of the onset of the last ice age, but also for the timing of the recovery of the climate system.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. Our data can be used to identify the locations of productive fisheries and the regions most at risk from overfishing, and can inform the design of policies to improve the sustainability of inland fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is designed to deliver a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3
This work is about the ability of neurons to regenerate, and it is about the ability of neurons to regenerate in the adult brain.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of the species and the diversity of its members. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

This work is a major advance in the study of the brain, because it provides a method for the direct study of the resting organization of the brain. This method is based on the analysis of the metabolic activity of the brain, which is a measure of the total activity of the neuronal population.
This is a study of the structure of the 5′ end of messenger RNA.

This study is a continuation of a previous study in which we found that epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are associated with the progression of microvascular complications over a period of 10 y. We now show that these DNA-me alterations are also associated with the metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also shows that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are associated with the progression of microvascular complications over a period of 10 y. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also shows that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are associated with the progression of microvascular complications over a period of 10 y. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also shows that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with
This is a study of the role of a protein in cancer.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The etiology of the disorder is unknown, but it is considered to be a brain disorder. The composition of the gut microbiota has recently been shown to be altered in psychiatric disorders, which suggests the possibility of a gut-to-brain interaction in the development of alcohol dependence. The aim of the present study was to explore whether changes in gut permeability are linked to gut-microbiota composition and activity in alcohol-dependent subjects. We also investigated whether gut dysfunction is associated with the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Finally, we tested the reversibility of the biological and behavioral parameters after a short-term detoxification program. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence, which may be important psychological factors of relapse. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. View Full-Text
This work is about the flavor of the tomato, and in particular, the role of the nitrogenous compounds in the aroma of the fruit.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because the impacts of climate change are expected to be most severe at the extremes of the temperature range. Our results have important implications for the conservation of biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems, and for the design of climate change mitigation strategies.
This study is about the brain, but it is also about the nature of science.
This study is about the flowering of plants, and it is about the flowering of animals.
This is a study of the brain’s dopamine system, which is involved in movement and motivation.

We show that the speed of communication is a robust predictor of how connected two people feel to each other. This effect is driven by the speed of communication between the two people, rather than the speed of communication between the two people and the listener.
This is a study of the heart, which is the most important organ in the human body.

This study is a continuation of our previous work on the role of silicon (Si) in plant resistance against insect herbivory. We have shown that Si can enhance resistance against herbivores by a number of mechanisms, including the promotion of Si accumulation in the plant. However, the role of silicon in the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway, which plays a crucial role in mediating antiherbivore defense responses in plants, has not been examined directly. Our results suggest that the promotion of Si accumulation by JA is a key mechanism in the enhancement of resistance against herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of silicon in plant resistance against insect herbivory. (Show more)
This is a study of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of the brain mechanisms that support language processing. We show that the brain can store information in the form of changes in the excitability of neuronal populations. This mechanism is sensitive to the context in which information is stored and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our results provide a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features and the integration of information over time. This work is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.
